chapterObjectives: Understand the principles of dynamic control in robotics.
Learn different control strategies for robotic systems.
Apply dynamic control methods to ensure stable and precise robot movements.

content.title: Introduction to Dynamic Control
paragraphs: Dynamic control in robotics involves using the principles of dynamics to design control systems that can accurately and efficiently move the robot. This goes beyond kinematic control by considering the forces and torques that drive the motion.

Understanding dynamic control is essential for achieving stable and precise movements, especially in tasks that require high performance, such as robotic arm manipulation, mobile robot navigation, and humanoid robot locomotion.

Dynamic control strategies take into account the robot's dynamics, including inertia, friction, and external forces, to provide robust and adaptive control solutions that ensure the robot performs as intended under various conditions.

content.title: PID Control
paragraphs: Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control is one of the most commonly used control strategies in robotics. It combines three types of control actions: proportional, integral, and derivative, each addressing different aspects of system performance.

Proportional control (P) provides a control output that is proportional to the error, which is the difference between the desired setpoint and the measured process variable. This type of control helps reduce the magnitude of the error.

Integral control (I) accumulates the error over time and provides a control output based on the total accumulated error. This helps eliminate steady-state error and ensures the system reaches the desired setpoint.
Derivative control (D) provides a control output based on the rate of change of the error. This helps predict future error and improves the stability and responsiveness of the system.

By combining these three control actions, PID control can provide precise and stable control for a wide range of robotic applications. The tuning of PID parameters (gain values) is crucial for achieving optimal performance.

content.title: Adaptive Control
paragraphs: Adaptive control is a control strategy that adjusts the control parameters in real-time based on the changing dynamics of the system. This is particularly useful for robots operating in uncertain or variable environments.

Adaptive control algorithms can learn and adapt to changes in the system, such as variations in payload, friction, and external disturbances. This ensures stable and robust performance even in the presence of uncertainties.

One common adaptive control technique is model reference adaptive control (MRAC), where the controller adjusts its parameters to match the behavior of a reference model. Another technique is adaptive gain scheduling, where the controller parameters are adjusted based on the operating conditions.
Adaptive control is beneficial in applications where the robot's environment or task conditions change frequently, requiring the control system to continuously adapt to maintain performance.

content.title: Robust Control
paragraphs: Robust control aims to maintain system performance despite uncertainties and disturbances. It designs controllers that can handle variations in system parameters and external disturbances, ensuring reliable operation under different conditions.

Robust control techniques include H-infinity control, which minimizes the worst-case gain of the system, and sliding mode control, which forces the system to follow a desired trajectory despite disturbances.
These techniques are particularly useful for robots operating in harsh or unpredictable environments, where precise modeling of the system dynamics is difficult or impossible.
Robust control provides a level of assurance that the robot will continue to perform its tasks effectively, even when faced with unexpected changes or errors in the system dynamics.

content.title: Model Predictive Control
paragraphs: Model predictive control (MPC) uses a model of the system to predict future behavior and optimize control actions. It solves an optimization problem at each control step, considering constraints and future states to determine the best control inputs.

MPC can handle multi-input multi-output (MIMO) systems and constraints on states and inputs, making it suitable for complex robotic systems. It provides a flexible and powerful control strategy that can adapt to changing conditions and optimize performance.

In MPC, the controller uses the system model to predict the future trajectory of the system over a finite time horizon. It then optimizes the control inputs to minimize a cost function while satisfying constraints. The first control input is applied, and the process is repeated at the next control step.
MPC is particularly useful in applications where the robot needs to operate in dynamic and constrained environments, such as autonomous driving and advanced manufacturing.

content.title: Applications of Dynamic Control in Robotics
paragraphs: Dynamic control is used in various robotic applications to achieve precise and stable motion control. In robotic arm manipulation, dynamic control algorithms are used to control the joint torques and ensure smooth and accurate movements.

In mobile robots, dynamic control is used to handle acceleration, deceleration, and turning, ensuring stable and efficient navigation. This is essential for tasks such as path following, obstacle avoidance, and autonomous driving.

In humanoid robots, dynamic control is used to coordinate limb movements, maintain balance, and perform complex tasks such as walking, running, and interacting with objects. Advanced control algorithms help these robots adapt to different terrains and environments.
In drones and aerial robots, dynamic control is used to manage flight dynamics, stability, and maneuverability. This ensures the drones can hover, navigate, and perform complex aerial maneuvers.

In surgical robotics, dynamic control is used to guide robotic instruments along precise trajectories during minimally invasive procedures. This ensures accurate targeting and minimizes damage to surrounding tissues.

Dynamic control also plays a crucial role in collaborative robots (cobots), which work alongside humans. These robots require precise control to ensure safety and efficiency in shared workspaces, adjusting their movements dynamically based on human interactions and environmental changes.
